speaker: Narrator
text: Kids, I'm going to tell you an incredible story. The story of how I met your mother

speaker: Son
text: Are we being punished for something?

speaker: Narrator
text: No

speaker: Daughter
text: Yeah, is this going to take a while?

speaker: Narrator
text: Yes. (Kids are annoyed) Twenty-five years ago, before I was dad, I had this whole other life.

speaker: Narrator
text: It was way back in 2005. I was twenty-seven just starting to make it as an architect and living in New York with my friend Marshall, my best friend from college. My life was good and then Uncle Marshall went and screwed the whole thing up.

speaker: Marshall
text: (Opens ring) Will you marry me.

speaker: Ted
text: Yes, perfect! And then you're engaged, you pop the champagne! You drink a toast! You have s*x on the kitchen floor... Don't have s*x on our kitchen floor.

speaker: Marshall
text: Got it. Thanks for helping me plan this out, Ted.

speaker: Ted
text: Dude, are you kidding? It's you and Lily! I've been there for all the big moments of you and Lily. The night you met. Your first date... other first things.

speaker: Marshall
text: (laughs) yeah, sorry. We thought you were asleep.

speaker: Ted
text: It's physics Marshall, if the bottom bunk moves, the top bunk moves too. My god, you're getting engaged tonight.

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah, what are you doing tonight?

speaker: Narrator
text: What was I doing? Your Uncle Marshall was taking the biggest step of his life, and me-I'm calling your Uncle, Barney.

speaker: Barney
text: (on the phone) hey, so you know how I've always had a thing for half-Asian girls? Well, now I've got a new favorite: Lebanese girls! Lebanese girls are the new half-Asians.

speaker: Ted
text: Hey, you wanna do something tonight?

speaker: Barney
text: Okay, meet me at the bar in fifteen minutes, and Suit up!

speaker: Ted
text: Hey.

speaker: Barney
text: Where's your suit!? Just once when I say suit up, I wish you'd put on a suit.

speaker: Ted
text: I did that one time.

speaker: Barney
text: It was a blazer!

speaker: Ted
text: You know, ever since college it's been Marshall and Lily and me. Now it's going to be Marshall and Lily... and me. They'll get married, start a family-before long I'm the weird, middle-aged bachelor their kids call "Uncle Ted".

speaker: Barney
text: I see what this is about. Have you forgotten what I said to you the night we met?

speaker: Barney
text: Ted, I'm going to teach you how to live. (Ted's shocked) Barney, we met at the urinal.

speaker: Ted
text: Oh, right. Hi.

speaker: Barney
text: Lesson one, lose the goatee. It doesn't look good with your suit.

speaker: Ted
text: I'm not wearing a suit.

speaker: Barney
text: Lesson two, get a suit. Suits are cool. (Points to self with bear bottle in hand) Exhibit A. (Flirts to a woman unseen) Lesson three, don't even think about getting married till you're... thirty.

speaker: Ted
text: Thirty, right. You're right. I guess it's just, you're best friend gets engaged-you start thinking about that stuff.

speaker: Barney
text: I thought I was your best friend. Ted, say I'm your best friend.

speaker: Ted
text: You're my best friend, Barney.

speaker: Barney
text: Good! And as your best friend, I suggest we play a little game called... "Have you met Ted?"

speaker: Ted
text: Wai-no, no, no. We're not playing "Have You Met Ted?"

speaker: Barney
text: (Taps a woman names Yasmine) Hi, have you met Ted? (Leaves and watches from a distance).

speaker: Ted
text: (To Yasmine) Hi, I'm Ted.

speaker: Yasmine
text: Yasmine.

speaker: Ted
text: It's a very pretty name.

speaker: Yasmine
text: Thanks, It's Lebanese.

speaker: Marshall
text: Hey!

speaker: Lily
text: Urgh. I'm exhausted. It was finger painting day at school, and a five year old boy (takes coat off revealing a purple hand print on her right breast) got to second base with me. Wow, you're cooking?

speaker: Marshall
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: Lily
text: Aww-(They kiss) Are you sure that's a good idea after last time? You looked really creepy without eyebrows.

speaker: Marshall
text: I can handle this; I'm full of surprises tonight.

speaker: Lily
text: So there's more surprises? Like what?

speaker: Narrator
text: Marshall was in his second year of law school, so he was pretty good at thinking on his feet.

speaker: Marshall
text: BOOGITY BOO! And that's all of them! I'm goanna go... cook. (Leaves)

speaker: Ted
text: I'm so happy for Marshall, I really am. I just couldn't imagine settling down right now.

speaker: Yasmine
text: So do you think you'll ever get married?

speaker: Ted
text: Well maybe eventually. Some fall day. Possibly in Central Park. Simple ceremony, we'll write our own vows. But--eh--no DJ, people will dance. I'm not going to worry about it! Damn it, why did Marshall have to get engaged? (Yasmine laughs) Yeah, nothing hotter than a guy planning out his own imaginary wedding, huh?

speaker: Yasmine
text: Actually, I think it's cute.

speaker: Ted
text: Well, you're clearly drunk (pulls her wine glass away. Hold up glass to bartender) ONE MORE FOR THE LADY!

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay, look what I got (runs to the fridge. Takes out wine bottle)

speaker: Lily
text: Aw-honey. Champagne! (hands it to Marshall)

speaker: Marshall
text: (after short silence) Yeah. (hands it back)

speaker: Lily
text: (realizing) No, you are too old to be scared to open a bottle of champagne!

speaker: Marshall
text: I'm not scared.

speaker: Lily
text: Then open it!

speaker: Marshall
text: Fine (takes bottle. Looks at it for a couple of seconds) Please open it (hands it to Lily)

speaker: Lily
text: You are unbelievable, Marshall. No-(Scene splits in half and shows both Lily and Marshall on top arguing and Ted and Yasmine on the bottom mingling)

speaker: Narrator
text: There are two big questions a man has to ask in life. One you plan out for months, the other just slips out when you're half drunk at some bar.

speaker: Marshall
text: (To Lily) will you marry me?

speaker: Ted
text: (To Yasmine) you wanna go out sometime?

speaker: Lily
text: Of course, you idiot! (hugs him and they fall back)

speaker: Yasmine
text: I'm sorry; Carl's my boyfriend (points to bartender)

speaker: Ted
text: Sup, Carl?

speaker: Marshall
text: I promised Ted we wouldn't do that.

speaker: Lily
text: Did you know there's a pop tart under your fridge?

speaker: Marshall
text: No, but dibs. Where's that champagne? I wanna drink a toast with my fiancé.

speaker: Lily
text: aww (claps. They kiss)

speaker: Marshall
text: I don't know why I was so scared of this. Pretty easy right? (Pops cork, hit's Lily's eye)

speaker: Lily
text: (YELLS)

speaker: Marshall
text: (covers mouth) OH!

speaker: Ted
text: Why am I freaking out all of a sudden? This is crazy! I'm not ready to settle down.

speaker: Barney
text: (ignoring) how does Carl land a Lebanese girl?

speaker: Ted
text: It's always been "don't even think about it till you're thirty"

speaker: Barney
text: Exactly-the guy doesn't even own a suit!

speaker: Ted
text: Plus Marshall's found the love of his life. Even if I was ready, which I'm not, but if I was it's like, "Okay, I'm ready! Where is she?" (Spots Robin)

speaker: Narrator
text: and there she was.

speaker: Narrator
text: It was like something from an old movie. Where the sailor sees the girl across the crowded dance floor, turns to his buddy and says, "see that girl? I'm going to marry her someday"

speaker: Ted
text: Hey Barney, see that girl?

speaker: Barney
text: (to Robin) Hey, have you met Ted?

speaker: Robin
text: Let me guess, (points) Ted?

speaker: Marshall
text: I'm sorry, Lily. I'm so sorry. Take us to the hospital.

speaker: Cabdriver
text: Whoa, whoa, whoa-did you hit her?

speaker: Lily
text: Hit me? Please, this guy could barely even spank me in bed for fun. He's all like, (hits ice in bag using to cover eye) "Oh, did that hurt?" and I'm like, "Come on, let me have it you pansy!" (realizes) Wow, complete stranger.

speaker: Cabdriver
text: no, no, no, no-it's okay, go on. (Turns meter on.) So these, spankin's...you in pajamas or going "naturelle"

speaker: Ted
text: So what do you do?

speaker: Robin
text: I'm a reporter for Metro News 1.

speaker: Ted
text: (nods) Oh.

speaker: Robin
text: Well, kind of a reporter. I do those dumb little fluff pieces at the end of the news, you know. Like-um-monkey that can play the ukulele. I'm hoping to get some bigger stories soon.

speaker: Ted
text: Bigger like, uh, gorilla with an up-right bass? Sorry, you're really pretty. (Robin laughs and waves to her friends) Oh, your friends don't seem too happy.

speaker: Robin
text: Yeah, see the one in the middle just got dumped by her boyfriend so tonight every guy is... "The enemy".

speaker: Ted
text: You know if you don't make your friend feel better you could throw a drink at my face. I don't mind.

speaker: Robin
text: She would love that! It does look fun in the movies.

speaker: Ted
text: Hey, you wanna have dinner with me Saturday night?

speaker: Robin
text: Oh, I can't. I'm going to Orlando for a week on Friday. Some guys attempting to make a big (cut) so my news is covering it.

speaker: Ted
text: That's going to take a week?

speaker: Robin
text: Yeah, he's going to eat it too, it's another record.

speaker: Robin's Dumped Friend
text: Hey, what's taking so long?

speaker: Ted
text: Uh, I know this is a long shot, but how about tomorrow night?

speaker: Robin
text: (stops) Yeah, (agrees) What the hell (passes number to Ted. Throws drink on Ted's face) JERK! (Walks away. Whispers) that was fun.

speaker: Barney
text: (comes back laughing) De-wait for it-nied! Denied!

speaker: Ted
text: We're going out tomorrow night.

speaker: Barney
text: I thought we were playing laser tag tomorrow night?

speaker: Ted
text: Yeah, I was never going to go play laser tag. (Wipes alcohol off his face)

speaker: Narrator
text: The next night, I took her out to this little bistro in Brooklyn.

speaker: Robin
text: Wow that is one bad-ass blue French horn.

speaker: Ted
text: Yeah.

speaker: Robin
text: Mhmm.

speaker: Ted
text: Sort of looks like a... Smurf pen1s.

speaker: Narrator
text: Son, a piece of advice. When you go on a first date you really don't wanna say "smurf pen1s". Girls don't ordinarily like that.

speaker: Narrator
text: But that was no ordinary girl.

speaker: Marshall
text: Lilly?

speaker: Lily
text: How long have you been sitting there!? Stupid eye patch.

speaker: Ted
text: Mom, dad, I have found the future Mrs. Ted Mosby! Marshall, how have I always described my perfect woman?

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh let's see (thinks) she likes dogs?

speaker: Robin
text: I've got five dogs.
Marshall:...she drinks scotch?

speaker: Robin
text: I love a scotch that's old enough to order its own scotch.

speaker: Marshall
text: Can quote obscure lines from "Ghostbusters"?

speaker: Robin
text: Ray, when someone asks you if you're a god you say, "Yes!"

speaker: Ted
text: And I'm saving the best for last.

speaker: Robin
text: Do you want these? (Holding up remaining olives from her plate) I hate olives.

speaker: Marshall
text: She hates olives! Awesome!

speaker: Lily
text: The olive theory.

speaker: Ted
text: The olive theory is based on my friends, Marshall and Lily. He hates olives, she loves them. In a weird way that's what makes them such a great couple. A Perfect balance (eats olive).

speaker: Robin
text: You know, I've had a jar of olives just sitting in my fridge forever.

speaker: Ted
text: (flirting) I can take them off your hands.

speaker: Robin
text: (flirting back) they're all yours.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh, it is on! It is on (imitates robot) till the break of dawn.

speaker: Lily
text: wait, it's only the break of ten-thirty. What happened?

speaker: Robin
text: I've gotta get one of those blue French horns for over my fireplace. It's gotta be blue, it's gotta be French.

speaker: Ted
text: No Green Clarinet?

speaker: Robin
text: No.

speaker: Ted
text: Come on, no purple tuba?

speaker: Robin
text: It's a smurf pen1s, we're no dice.

speaker: Producer
text: (from inside van) there you are! We've got a jumper! Some crazy guy on the Manhattan Bridge. Come on, you're covering it!

speaker: Robin
text: Um, alright. I'll be right there. (To Ted) I'm sorry. I had a really great time tonight.

speaker: Ted
text: Yeah.

speaker: Marshall
text: So? Did you kiss her?

speaker: Ted
text: No. The moment wasn't right. (They sigh) Look, this woman could be my future wife; I want our first kiss to be amazing.

speaker: Lily
text: Aww, Ted that's so sweet. So you chickened out like the little bitch.

speaker: Ted
text: What? I did not chicken out! You know what? I don't need to take first kiss advice from some pirate who hasn't been single since the first week of college.

speaker: Lily
text: Ted, anyone who's single would tell you the same thing. Even the dumbest single person alive, and if you don't believe me...call him.

speaker: Barney
text: (Phone) Hey loser, how's not playing laser tag? Because playing laser tag is awesome! Oh, I k*lled you Connor; don't make me get your mom!

speaker: Ted
text: Hey, listen. I need your opinion on something.

speaker: Barney
text: Okay, meet me at the bar in fifteen minutes-AND SUIT UP!

speaker: Ted
text: So these guys think I chickened out. What do you think?

speaker: Barney
text: I can't believe you're still not wearing a SUIT!

speaker: Ted
text: She didn't even give me the signal.

speaker: Barney
text: What is she goanna-is she goanna bat her eyes at you in Morse code (bats eyes)?? Ted (bats eyes) Kiss me-No, you just kiss her!

speaker: Ted
text: Not if you don't get the signal.

speaker: Barney
text: Ee-(Kisses Marshal) Did Marshall give me the signal?

speaker: Marshall
text: No! (To Lily) I didn't, I swear.

speaker: Barney
text: But see-at least, tonight, I get to sleep knowing, Marshall and Me... never going to happen. You should've kissed her.

speaker: Ted
text: Urgh, I should've kissed her. What about when she gets back from Orlando?

speaker: Barney
text: A week? That's like-a year in hot girl time. She'll forget all about you. Mark my words: you will never see that one again.

speaker: Ted
text: There she is...

speaker: Lily
text: Ooo. She's cute! (To Carl) Hey Carl, turn it up!

speaker: Robin
text: (on TV)...persuaded him to reconsider at which point the man came down off the ledge, giving this bizarre story a happy ending. Reporting from

speaker: Marshall
text: Huh, guy didn't jump

speaker: Robin
text: (on TV) Metro One News, back to you bill.

speaker: Ted
text: I'm goanna go kiss her. Right now.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh-Dude, it's midnight. As your future lawyer I'm goanna advise you: that's freakin' crazy!

speaker: Ted
text: I never do anything crazy! I'm always waiting for the moment! Planning the moment! Well she's leaving tomorrow this may be the only moment I'm goanna get! I gotta do what that guy couldn't, I gotta take the leap! Okay not a perfect metaphor, for me it's fall in love and get married-for him it's... death.

speaker: Barney
text: Actually, that is a perfect metaphor. By the way, did I congratulate you two? (Raises glass to Lily and Marshall)

speaker: Ted
text: I'm doing this. (Starts to leave)

speaker: Lily
text: Let's go (pulls Marshall up)

speaker: Marshall
text: Word up!

speaker: Lily
text: We're coming with you.
Ted:...Barney?

speaker: Barney
text: Alright, but under one condition.

speaker: Barney
text: (happy) look at you, you beautiful b*st*rd, you suited up! This is totally going in my blog!

speaker: Ted
text: (To Ranjit-Cabdriver) Stop the car. Uh-pull over right here. I gotta do something.

speaker: Ted
text: Excuse me, pardon me. (grabs the Blue French Horn) Enjoy your coffee. (Runs away)

speaker: Waitor
text: Hey, HEY!

speaker: Ted
text: go, go, GO! (looks to his friends. Shrugs) Everybody brings flowers.

speaker: Ted
text: (Exhales) Okay. Moment of truth. Wish me luck. (Exhales)

speaker: Barney
text: Ted's goanna get it on with a TV reporter (nods. Laughs.) This just in. Okay (holds hand up for high-fives)

speaker: Lily
text: Kiss her, Ted. Kiss her good.

speaker: Marshall
text: Kiss the crap out of that girl

speaker: Ted
text: Marshall, remember this night. When you're the best man at our wedding and you give a speech, you're goanna tell this story. (exits cab)

speaker: Barney
text: Why does he get to be the best man? (Shouts out) I'M YOUR BEST FRIEND!

speaker: Narrator
text: As I walked up to that door a million thoughts raced through my mind. Unfortunately, one particular thought did not.

speaker: Robin
text: I've got five dogs.

speaker: Ted
text: Not good, not good, not good, not good.

speaker: Lily
text: No!

speaker: Marshall
text: Go back in there!

speaker: Barney
text: You're wearing a suit!

speaker: Robin
text: (from window) Ted?

speaker: Ted
text: Hi! (Silence) I was just uh-(hold up Smurf pen1s, aka French Horn)

speaker: Robin
text: Come on up.

speaker: Marshall
text: He's in.

speaker: Barney
text: So, (looks to the cabdriver) Ranjit... you must've done it with a Lebanese girl.

speaker: Lily
text: Okay-that's my Barney Limit. (Starts to leave the cab) I'm goanna see if that Bodega has a bathroom. (Leaves)

speaker: Ranjit
text: Actually, I'm from Bangladesh.

speaker: Barney
text: The women hot there?

speaker: Ranjit
text: Here's a picture of my wife! (Shows picture)

speaker: Barney
text: (Whispers to Marshall) Simple no would have sufficed. (To Ranjit) She's lovely.

speaker: Robin
text: So, Ted. What brings you back to Brooklyn at one in the morning in a-suit.

speaker: Ted
text: I was just hoping to get those olives... that you said I could have.

speaker: Robin
text: Would you like those olives with some Gin and Vermouth?

speaker: Ted
text: Are you trying to get me drunk?

speaker: Robin
text: For starters (turns music on. Leaves to the kitchen)

speaker: Ted
text: (Looks up and mouths) Thank you.

speaker: Barney
text: So, Marshall. This "Olive Theory" based on you and Lily?

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah...

speaker: Barney
text: You hate olives? Lily loves them, you can't stand them.

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah, hate olives.

speaker: Barney
text: Two weeks ago, Spanish bar on 79th Street, dish of olives-you had some. What up?

speaker: Marshall
text: (looks around for sign of Lily) You have to swear that this does not leave this cab.

speaker: Barney
text: I swear.

speaker: Ranjit
text: (Cuts into conversation) I swear.

speaker: Marshall
text: On our first date, I ordered a Greek salad; Lily asked if she could have my olives. I said, "Sure... I hate olives."

speaker: Barney
text: But you like olives!

speaker: Marshall
text: Well, I was eighteen, okay? I was a virgin. Been waiting for my whole life for a pretty girl to want my olives.

speaker: Barney
text: Marshall, I'm going to get you an early wedding present. Don't get married.

speaker: Robin
text: I think I like your "Olive Theory".

speaker: Ted
text: I think I like your French Horn.

speaker: Robin
text: I think I like your nose.

speaker: Ted
text: I think I'm in love with you.
Lily, Marshall and Barney: What?

speaker: Son and Daughter
text: What?

speaker: Robin
text: What?

speaker: Barney
text: Come on man, you said your stomach's been hurting, right? You know what that is! Hunger. You're hungry for experience. Hungry for something new. Hungry for olives. But you're too scared to do anything about it.

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah, I'm scared, okay? But when I think about spending the rest of my life with Lily... committing forever, no other women (Lily appears behind Marshall in the open window) doesn't scare me at all. I'm marrying that girl. (Lily pops her head in from the window. Marshall turns around) Lily. Lily, I like olives.

speaker: Lily
text: We'll make it work. (They kiss.)

speaker: Ranjit
text: aww.

speaker: Ted
text: So Orlando, you goanna hit Disney World?

speaker: Robin
text: You love me?

speaker: Ted
text: Oh, god, I can't believe I said that. Why did I say that? Who says that? I should just go. (Gets up)

speaker: Robin
text: Hold on. (Gets up) Wait a minute. (Hands him Olives) Promised you these.

speaker: Ted
text: Olives. Thanks. I love you. What's wrong with me?

speaker: Barney
text: Why are we still sitting here? Let's go! We can still make last call. What do you say Lil? (Pirate Accent) Yo, ho ho and a bottle o' rum? (Silence) 'Cuz you're a pirate...

speaker: Lily
text: Okay, eye patch gone-(takes eye patch off and throws it at Barney) And we can't just abandon Ted. If it doesn't go well up there he's gonna need some support.

speaker: Marshall
text: It's been like twenty minutes. You think they're doin' it?

speaker: Barney
text: You think they're doing it in front of the dogs?

speaker: Marshall
text: Doggie style. (Laughs)

speaker: Barney
text: I had this girl in college; she had a golden retriever-

speaker: Lily
text: Okay, we can go to the bar, just stop talking.

speaker: Barney
text: Hit it Ranjit. (They drive off)

speaker: Ted
text: So when you tell this story to your friends, could you avoid the word "psycho"? I prefer...eccentric.

speaker: Robin
text: Good night, psycho (smiles). (Ted sarcastically clutches heart. Realizes friends left him)

speaker: Ted
text: Great (before Robin closes the door) Umm... how do I get to the F Train?

speaker: Robin
text: Oh, um-two blocks (comes out) that way (points) and take a right.

speaker: Ted
text: (upset/tired) Thanks. (Walks down the steps. Robin begins to walk in) You know what? (Robin stops. Ted turns around). I'm done being single. I'm not good at it. Look, obviously you can't tell a woman you just met you love her. But... it sucks that you can't. I'll tell you something though, if a woman-not you... just some hypothetical woman-were to bare with me through all this. I think I'd make a damn good husband. Because that's the stuff I'd be good at. Stuff like making her laugh and being a good father... and walking her five hypothetical dogs. Being a good kisser.

speaker: Robin
text: Everyone thinks they're a good kisser.

speaker: Ted
text: Oh, I've got references.

speaker: Robin
text: Good night, Ted. (Shake hands.)

speaker: Ted
text: And I'm a good hand shaker

speaker: Robin
text: that's a pretty great hand shake. (Looks him in the eyes)

speaker: Ted
text: And that was it, probably never see her again. (Silence) What?

speaker: Marshall
text: That was the signal!

speaker: Lily
text: That long lingering handshake-you should've kissed her!

speaker: Barney
text: There's no such thing as the signal. But yeah-that was the signal.

speaker: Rangit
text: Signal (nods)

speaker: Marshal
text: Ah, Carl thank you. Something I gotta do.

speaker: Carl
text: By the way, you should've kissed her.

speaker: Ted
text: Carl!? (turns to friends) You guys weren't there.

speaker: Lily
text: I am so turned on right now.

speaker: Ted
text: Guys, trust me. I've seen the signal. That was not the signal.

speaker: Barney
text: Yeah Ted, we're not on you anymore.

speaker: Marshall
text: (Toasting) To my fiancé!

speaker: Lily
text: (smiles) to the future!

speaker: Ranjit
text: To one hell of a night!

speaker: Ted
text: That was not the signal!

speaker: Narrator
text: I asked her about it years later, and yeah, that was the signal. I could've kissed her. But that's the funny thing about destiny.
Narrator:... it happens whether you plan it or not. I mean I...
Narrator:... never thought I'd see that girl again. But it...
Narrator:...turns out, I was just too close...
Narrator:...to the puzzle to see the picture that was forming. Because that kids...
Narrator:...is the true story, of how I met your Aunt Robin.

speaker: Son
text: Aunt Robin?

speaker: Daughter
text: I thought this was about how you met mom!

speaker: Narrator
text: Will you relax? I'm getting to it. (Son and daughter sit back unpleased) like I said:
Narrator:...it's a long story.

speaker: Narrator
text: Okay, where was I?

speaker: Daughter
text: You were telling us how you met mom.

speaker: Son
text: In excruciating detail...

speaker: Narrator
text: Right, so (While Flashbacks take place) back in 2005 when I was twenty-seven, my two best friends got engaged. And it got me thinking, "Maybe I should get married." Then I saw... Robin. She was incredible. I just knew I had to meet her. That's where your Uncle Barney came in.

speaker: Barney
text: I suggest we play a little game I like to call, "Have you Met Ted?"

speaker: Ted
text: No, no, no-we're not playing "Have you Met Ted!"

speaker: Barney
text: (Taps Robin's shoulder) Hi! Have you met Ted? (Leaves)

speaker: Narrator
text: So I asked her out, and I know this sounds crazy... but after just one date, I was in love with her, which made me say something stupid

speaker: Ted
text: I think I'm in love with you.

speaker: Robin
text: What?

speaker: Daughter
text: Oh, Dad.

speaker: Son
text: So then what happened?

speaker: Narrator
text: Nothing. I mean, I made a complete fool of myself. So... a week went by and I decided not to call her.

speaker: Marshall
text: So you're not goanna call her? You went from, "I think I'm in love with you" to "I'm not gonna call her?"

speaker: Ted
text: I wasn't in love with her, okay? I was briefly in love with the abstract idea of getting married! That had absolutely nothing to do with Robin. (Finds Lily and Robin chatting at a table.) Robin!

speaker: Robin

text: Why do I hang out with you? Why? All I wanted was to have a regular beer, in a regular bar with my regular friends, in my regular city!

text: Look, our forefathers died for the pursuit of happiness, okay. Not for the sit around and wait of happiness. Cabdriver#2: That was beautiful, man!

text: Thanks, Leonard. Ted, you're missing out on a valuable life lesson!

text: Because, you're my best friend, alright? You don't have to tell me I'm yours. But the way I see it, we're a team. Without you, I'm just the dynamic uno. You know what, fine. If you wanna go home... then we'll go home.

text: Kids, when you're single all you're looking for is happily ever after. But only one of your stories can end that way. The rest end with someone getting hurt. This is one of those stories, and it starts... with a shirt.

text: That's the crazy part. I've had this shirt for, like, six years... Until this morning I wasn't into it at all, but now it's like my tastes have changed.

text: Booger.

text: Yes, hello, Barney.

text: Aaah, point is. I seem to like bourbon now. I could have sworn I hated bourbon. First the shirt, now bourbon. I spent twenty-seven years making up my mind about things, right? The movie I saw once in Haden, the city I'll never go back to because it was raining the day I visited. Maybe it's time to start forming some second impressions...

text: You're finally gonna watch "Goonies AGAIN? Slow love, Chuck".

text: (Laughs) Not Goonies, girls. What if there's someone from my past, who I thought was wrong for me at the time, but in fact she, like my shirt, is actually a perfect fit?

text: Hold up, there are only two reasons to date a girl you've already dated. Breast, Implants.

text: Steph...

text: A-hundred-and-seventy-five.

text: (laughs with Ted) I know the feeling, once... when I was sixteen, I was driving, and I hit this hitchhiker. Don't know what happened to him... just kept drivin'! (Laughs)

text: Uh...no.

text: Natalie, I had so many fond memories of her. The tea candles on her dresser. The sock monkey collection on her bed. That one Belle and Sebastian song that she always listened to. Her smile.

text: You dumped a p*rn star? Friendship over (gets up) FRIENDSHIP OVER!

text: So, next time you're passing City Hall, make sure and stop by New York's oldest hotdog cart. Today a delicious hotdog will cost you $2.50, but back when the stand first opened in 1955, you could get one for only a nipple. Reporting live, Robin Scherbatsky, Metro News One.

text: Well baby really likes, is the thrill of pulling one over on those bean counters, who under appreciate you and still haven't promoted you. And for two more hundy-sticks, baby's going to look in the camera and say this (Whispers in her ear)

speaker: Lily
text: Scooter, you're gonna be an umpire someday.

speaker: Scooter
text: No, baby. We're gonna be an umpire someday.

speaker: Barney
text: Nice. You ladies look good, but your outfits are missing just one thing.

speaker: Robin
text: No, Barney, this is as far as we're going to go. I'm not showing anymore...

speaker: Barney
text: Two beautiful flowers for two beautiful flowers.

speaker: Lily
text: Aw. Sweet. Thank you.

speaker: Barney
text: Oh, Robin, are you tearing up?

speaker: Robin
text: No. I've never been to prom before, okay?

speaker: Lily
text: We got to go. See ya.

speaker: Ted
text: Bye, have fun. See you.

speaker: Marshall
text: They grow up into skanks so fast, don't they, Ted?

speaker: Ted
text: So, what, we ready for tonight?

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah. Just one thing we got to do first.

speaker: Ted
text: Shot of Jim Beam?

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah.

speaker: Ted
text: Yes!

speaker: Marshall
text: And then I promised Lily that we'd stuff 200 wedding invitations.

speaker: Ted
text: What?!

speaker: Marshall
text: I'm sorry, dude, but you saw how stressed out she is.

speaker: Ted
text: Come on! You've been doing wedding stuff nonstop. Take a break. Once you're married, if we go out and you get so drunk you throw up, it'll be sad, but if we do it tonight... it'll be less sad.

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay, it'll be cool-- I'll tell you what. We'll make a game out of it. First one to stuff a hundred invitations gets a big prize.

speaker: Ted
text: Do I look like I'm four? All right, what kind of prize are we talking?

speaker: Lily
text: Wow, a lot more security than when we were kids.

speaker: Robin
text: Is this gonna work?

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah. Look, when I was 17, I used to sneak into clubs all the time. It's all about confidence. Follow me. Whee-hoo! Happy prom, everybody. Going to prom-- whee-hoo!

speaker: Security guard
text: Uh, you're adults.

speaker: Lily
text: Okay, bye. Okay, look, I just need to see the band. I'm getting married in two months, and...

speaker: Security guard
text: And you're just finding a band?

speaker: Barney
text: Hey, ho, hey!

speaker: Security guard
text: I'm sorry, ma'am. You either need to be a student or the date of a student.

speaker: Lily
text: Wow. "Ma'am?" Check and mate.

speaker: Barney
text: It's cool. Time to activate plan B. Scherbotsky, how comfortable are you with a crossbow? Scherbotsky?

speaker: Robin
text: Hey, guys. Do you want to take two hot girls to prom?

speaker: Boy
text: We don't have that kind of money.

speaker: Robin
text: For free.

speaker: Boy
text: Oh, hell yeah!

speaker: Robin
text: Great. I'm Robin, this is my friend Lily.

speaker: Lily
text: Hi. Shall we?

speaker: Boy
text: Sure. I knew it would happen. This is the dream.

speaker: Robin
text: Oh, hey, wait. How's Barney getting in?

speaker: Barney
text: Don't worry about me. I'll get in. Oh... I'll get in.

speaker: Lily
text: We're in!

speaker: Singer
text: Thank you. We're going to take a break.

speaker: Lily
text: Oh, you're kidding me.
Boy #1: Hey, uh, you ladies want something to take the edge off?

speaker: Robin
text: Yeah, what the hell? It's prom. That tastes like cough syrup.
Boy #1: Yeah, we couldn't get any alcohol. Um, our fake IDs say we're only 20. We didn't realize it till after we bought them.

speaker: Robin
text: Nerds who aren't good at math? Life's going to be rough, boys.

speaker: Lily
text: Hi. Excuse me. I was wondering if you guys could play "Good Feeling" by the Violent Femmes. I know it's probably not in your repertoire, but I'm getting married and my fiancé wants to hire you guys as the band, but I can't sign off on it until I hear you play "Good Feeling" because that's our song, and what kind of wedding band would you be if you couldn't play our song, right? Right?

speaker: Man
text: Look, I'm kinda wasted right now, so I didn't understand any of that. But, uh, if you get us the sheet music, we'll play your song.
Boy #1: So, you buzzing, baby?

speaker: Robin
text: My phlegm feels looser.

speaker: Ted
text: This is pathetic. It's guys' night. We should be out in a bar getting in fights. If I got in a fight, would you have my back?

speaker: Marshall
text: You know it.

speaker: Ted
text: I'd have your back, too.

speaker: Marshall
text: That's cool.

speaker: Ted
text: What, you don't think you'd need my help? You don't know what I can do. I'm like... like a berserker.

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay, Ted. (His phone starts rigging) Hello.

speaker: Robin
text: Hey, it's Robin. Um, Lily needs you to download the sheet music for "Good Feeling" and bring it out here, like, now.

speaker: Marshall
text: Hang on. It's Robin. She wants me to go to prom. Can Ted come?

speaker: Ted
text: Wait! Don't ask! That's so lame! I don't even want to go anyway.

speaker: Robin
text: Uh, I don't know. Things have been so weird between us.

speaker: Ted
text: What'd she say? What'd she say?

speaker: Robin
text: He lied and told me he broke up with his girlfriend to try to hook up with me. I mean, I know he apologized for it but it's just, it's not easy to forgive. Look, if you absolutely must bring Ted, it's, it's not like I'm going to claw my own eyes out if he comes.

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay, bye. She totally wants you to come.

speaker: Robin
text: All right, sheet music's on the way. Are you okay?

speaker: Lily
text: There's just so much to do for this wedding. My head is swirling. It's just all moving too fast.

speaker: Scooter
text: How is it moving too fast? We've been together for two years.

speaker: Lily
text: I just... I just don't want everything in my life to be decided already.

speaker: Scooter
text: What's decided? I go to umpire school, you go to college. We move into my dad's house in Staten Island. We have kids, we grow old together. What's decided? It's wide open!

speaker: Lily
text: Scooter, when I go off to college, that's the end for us.

speaker: Scooter
text: You're, you're breaking up with me?

speaker: Lily
text: There's still so much I want to do. I want to travel, live overseas as an artist, maybe have a lesbian relationship. Plus, I think I was just dating you 'cause you look a little bit like Kurt Cobain.

speaker: Scooter
text: I can't believe this. I can change. I can look more like Kurt Cobain. Please, just don't leave me. I'm nothing without you, baby.

speaker: Lily
text: Please don't put that kind of pressure on me! It's too much!
Boy #2: It's just one dance, God!

speaker: Lily
text: What?

speaker: Robin
text: Well, we did promise them one dance.

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah, sure, okay. So Andrew, what's your big plan? What's life going to be like after tonight?

speaker: Andrew
text: Well, you know I got it all worked out. Uh, leave this place in my dust, four awesome years at college, and then I'll move to Prague or start my own video game company or something.

speaker: Lily
text: No, you won't.

speaker: Andrew
text: I won't?

speaker: Lily
text: No, you won't accomplish anything you set out to. You'll get a girlfriend the first day of college and you'll give up your independence and you'll never live abroad and you'll wind up old before your time wondering "Whatever happened to my hopes and my dreams?"

speaker: Andrew
text: Whoa. You really think I'll get a girlfriend?
Boy #1: So, uh, what's the deal here? Am I getting lucky tonight?

speaker: Robin
text: Oh, Sean, look, um, you're a nice guy, but I just don't... No, you're not getting lucky tonight.

speaker: Giant Turtle
text: Okay, just be cool. Don't look at me.

speaker: Ted
text: Okay.

speaker: Giant Turtle
text: How'd you get in here?

speaker: Marshall
text: What's it to you, giant turtle?

speaker: Giant Turtle
text: It's me, Barney.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh, hey. Where's Lily?

speaker: Barney
text: She's in the bathroom.

speaker: Marshall
text: Wait here, I should go talk to the band.

speaker: Ted
text: All right.

speaker: Barney
text: How did you guys get in here?

speaker: Ted
text: We just snuck in the back.

speaker: Barney
text: You just snu... Are you serious? I've been trying to get in here all night. I finally paid a janitor 200 bucks to let me borrow this mascot costume.

speaker: Ted
text: But you got in. Slow and steady won the race.

speaker: Marshall
text: Hey, bro, have you seen my fiancée Lily?

speaker: Andrew
text: Your fiancée? Whoa, tonight she's with me, bro. Unless you're looking for trouble.

speaker: Marshall
text: Listen, little buddy, I understand it's prom and the adrenaline's pumping, but...

speaker: Andrew
text: No, not tonight. I've waited too long for this. I finally got a girl and I'm not going to let you take her away from me.

speaker: Marshall
text: Whoa, whoa. Look, let's not get carried away.

speaker: Andrew
text: Yah! Nunchaku!

speaker: Lily
text: I can't believe I unloaded like that on a high school senior.

speaker: Robin
text: I can't believe a high school senior unloaded like that on me. I'm going to ask you something and, um, maybe it's crazy 'cause you guys are the cutest couple ever. But, um, are you having second thoughts?

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah. But not about Marshall. About me. I just keep thinking about the girl I was ten years ago and wondering what happened to her.

speaker: Lily
text: I don't want to be tied down. I want to live in France and Spain and Italy and just soak up life and put it on a canvas, even if it means being a waitress in crappy cafés for five years, I don't care. I'm going to be a painter. And I can't do any of that with a, with a boyfriend shackled around my neck, you know? But anyway, I'm blabbering. Way to make new friends, Lily. I'm sorry. What was your name again?

speaker: Man
text: Marshall.

speaker: Lily
text: Nice to meet you, Marshall. Guess we're hallmates.

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah.

speaker: Lily
text: It works.

speaker: Marshall
text: Violent Femmes. I love this song.

speaker: Lily
text: Me, too.

speaker: Lily
text: I didn't have any of the experiences I set out to. The travel, the bohemian art life, my big lesbian experience. I didn't do any of it.

speaker: Robin
text: Lily, you're marrying your best friend in the world. I mean, isn't that worth all the other experiences combined?

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah.

speaker: Robin
text: And look, you can still travel, I mean, you can still paint. And as far as your lesbian experience... Happy?

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah. So field hockey, huh?

speaker: Robin
text: Shut up.
Security guard #1: Trespassing, assaulting a minor. This mascot costume you stole cost $5,000.
Security guard #2: We can have you guys arrested, you know that?

speaker: Ted
text: Oh, come on-- you're the one who let in a kid with nunchakus. You call yourself security guards? I was just defending my boy here.

speaker: Marshall
text: I totally could have taken that kid.

speaker: Ted
text: Uh, yeah, and I totally had your back, so...

speaker: Marshall
text: Well, I don't need it, but thanks.

speaker: Ted
text: Uh, yeah, you did, and you're welcome.

speaker: Marshall
text: No, the kid was totally, like, a white belt and I'm gigantic. Listen, guys, I'm sorry. Please, I just need to get in there for one more song.

speaker: Security guards
text: Absolutely not.

speaker: Barney
text: You guys will thank me for this later, okay? Listen, Don, Ray, can't we all...?
Security guard #1: Hey!

speaker: Ted
text: You know, for a turtle, he's surprisingly quick.

speaker: Singer
text: This one goes out to that redhead girl and that tall guy.

speaker: Ted
text: So how was your first prom?

speaker: Robin
text: You tell me. I hated my dress, my date got wasted and puked on me, there was a huge fight and I kissed a girl.

speaker: Ted
text: So, basically, it was a prom.

speaker: Robin
text: Okay, I've missed you. Not in a we're-going-to-make-out way, not even in an I-forgive-you way. Just in a I've-missed-you way.

speaker: Ted
text: I'll take what I can get.

speaker: Barney
text: And that, my friends, is why you don't get your money's worth when you wear jeans to a strip club.

speaker: Marshall
text: So you got to admit, The 88 are rocking our song.

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah, it's good.

speaker: Marshall
text: Band? Check. Two months, baby. Two months.

speaker: Lily
text: Two months.
Ted from 2030: Kids, life is a dark road. You never really know what's up ahead. One night you're cruising along enjoying the ride, and then all of a sudden, you're 28.

speaker: Waitress
text: And for the birthday boy, lasagna.

speaker: Ted
text: Thank you.

speaker: Waitress
text: Careful. The plate is very hot.

speaker: Ted
text: 'Kay. Oh, go on, touch it.

speaker: Lily
text: Ah! Sweet damn, that's a hot plate.

speaker: Ted
text: All right, so, Barney, are you doing this or what?

speaker: Robin
text: Oh, geez, Barney, don't do this.

speaker: Barney
text: I have to, it's my birthday present to Ted.

speaker: Marshall
text: You don't have to. Please, it's going to be embarrassing and we're going to have to stop coming here, which will suck... in addition to probably being kind of healthy.

speaker: Ted
text: Come on, Marshall, it's the greatest pickup line of all time. Barney.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oy, gevalt.

speaker: Barney
text: Ah... Happy birthday, Ted.

speaker: Ted
text: Whoo-hoo!

speaker: Barney
text: Uh, excuse me, has anyone ever told y... Oh, my God.

speaker: Woman
text: What?

speaker: Barney
text: Oh! Call an ambulance!

speaker: Woman
text: What's going on?

speaker: Barney
text: Try not to speak. Here, sit down. Just don't talk, don't talk.

speaker: Waitress
text: Is she okay?

speaker: Barney
text: I'm serious, call 911.

speaker: Woman
text: What's wrong? What's the matter?

speaker: Barney
text: Shh! Shh! Just don't move. Don't move. Just try... Here, have some water. Water! Here, drink this. Shh! Shh!

speaker: Robin
text: You know, the more I watch this, the less convinced I am that it's the greatest pickup line of all time.

speaker: Ted
text: Wait for it.

speaker: Lily
text: 28. Two more 'til the big one, three-oh.
Ted from 2030: Actually, my 30th birthday wasn't so bad. Well, except for the goat in my bathroom. Which is a great story. But I'll get to that later.

speaker: Lily
text: Still, you know, another year older. Still single. You don't hear your Tedological clock ticking?

speaker: Ted
text: Nope. I hit the snooze button.

speaker: Robin
text: And here come the paramedics.

speaker: Barney
text: Oh, thank God, you're here.

speaker: Paramedic
text: What is going on?!

speaker: Barney
text: I think there might be some internal bleeding. Probably some fractures. We got to get her to the hospital.

speaker: Woman
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Barney
text: You've had a terrible fall.

speaker: Woman
text: No, I haven't.

speaker: Barney
text: Really? 'Cause I could swear you fell straight out of heaven. Angel... Give him your number. What? Give him your number. What?

speaker: All
text: Give him your number.

speaker: Barney
text: Come on, guys, you're embarrassing me.

speaker: All
text: Give him your number.

speaker: Barney
text: What are you...? Come on. They're not going to stop 'til you give me your number.

speaker: Woman
text: All right!

speaker: Barney
text: It works!

speaker: Marshall
text: I cannot believe that she gave him her number.

speaker: Robin
text: Maybe she really does have a brain injury.

speaker: Barney
text: Thank you, everyone. Thank you, everyone. It's been fun. It's Wendy the waitress. Tip her well. Thanks a lot, guys. Troilus and Cressida. Neighborhood Playhouse. Check them out, they're good.

speaker: Ted
text: I realize why I'm still single. I'm picky. I'm not going to settle. If I'm going to marry someone, she has to be perfect.

speaker: Lily
text: Well, what's perfect?

speaker: Ted
text: It's not like I have a list.

speaker: Robin
text: Oh, yes, you do.

speaker: Ted
text: Attractive, college-educated, she wants two kids-- a boy and a girl...

speaker: Lily
text: That's not hard. I know at least...

speaker: Ted
text: I'm not done. She likes dogs, Otis Redding, does the crossword. She's into sports, but not so much so that her legs are, like, more muscular than mine. That weirds me out. And she plays bass guitar like Kim Deal from the Pixies.

speaker: Marshall
text: Or Kim Gordon from Sonic Youth.

speaker: Ted
text: Any Kim from any cool band, really. Can't be too picky.

speaker: Lily
text: You're never going to find this girl.

speaker: Ted
text: Exactly. So I'm just going to wait for her to come to me. I am done trying to plan the unplannable.

speaker: Marshall
text: So, what, you think fate's just going to take care of it?

speaker: Ted
text: That's the plan.
Ted from 2030: And little did I know, at that very moment, fate... in the form of a 600 gigahertz superprocessing computer... was taking care of it.

speaker: Ted
text: Whoa, you're up early.

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah, thought I'd whip up some pancakes.

speaker: Ted
text: Does Marshall know?

speaker: Lily
text: He's still sound asleep.

speaker: Marshall
text: Awesome. So awesome. God! Best girl ever. Screw these pancakes, I should cover you in syrup and gobble you up.

speaker: Ted
text: Please don't do that. Hey, is this milk any good?

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh, yeah, that totally got me yesterday.

speaker: Ted
text: God, why didn't you throw it away?

speaker: Lily
text: I'm going shopping after work. I'll pick up some milk.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh...! These pancakes are delightful.

speaker: Lily
text: What's wrong, baby?

speaker: Marshall
text: This is the high point of my day.

Ted from 2030: It was true. See, Marshall had always dreamed of using his law degree to protect the environment. But he needed money for the wedding, so he'd been interning for two months at Barney's firm... and he hated every minute of it.

speaker: Marshall
text: Hey, Barney, I had some questions about filling out these requisition forms.

speaker: Barney
text: Binoculars. Second pair on my desk.

speaker: Marshall
text: I don't have time to be creepy, dude. I have a lot of work to do.

speaker: Barney
text: Just take a look, will ya? Okay, corner office. Top floor. Check out that guy. Name's Clark Butterfield. He works over at Nicholson, Hewitt and West and every morning, he orders a sandwich from the deli downstairs.

speaker: Marshall
text: So?

speaker: Barney
text: So guess what I did to that sandwich? Here, I took a picture.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh! Sweet Lord.

speaker: Barney
text: And now I'm e-mailing said picture to him.

speaker: Marshall
text: Ooh! Duck! That is sick! Why would you do that?

speaker: Barney
text: Who knows? This feud goes so far back I can't remember who fired the first shot.

speaker: Marshall
text: You?

speaker: Barney
text: Totally. Well, look, if you would just... help me fill out these forms, that would be great.

speaker: Marshall
text: What?

speaker: Barney
text: Butterfield is going to retaliate within the next four hours. That's been his pattern. This is war, Eriksen. I need you to clear your schedule, call Lily, tell her you'll be home late.

speaker: Marshall
text: This is stupid.

speaker: Barney
text: Stu... Come on, man, I didn't recruit you to work here for your lawyering skills. I recruited you to be my executive mischief consultant.

speaker: Marshall
text: This is a job for me, Barney. It's a way to make some extra wedding money, and that's it. Now I'm sorry, but I have work to do.

speaker: Barney
text: Tracy, could you come in here, please? Would you please inform Mr. Eriksen that I'm no longer speaking to him.

speaker: Tracy
text: Mr. Eriksen, Mr. Stinson is no longer...

speaker: Marshall
text: I get it. Thank you, Tracy.

speaker: Ted
text: Hello?

speaker: Man
text: Hello. May I speak with a Mr. Ted Mosby?

speaker: Ted
text: Speaking.

speaker: Man
text: Mr. Mosby, how you doing, sir? Bob Rorschach over here at Love Solutions. You signed up for our services about six months ago.

speaker: Ted
text: Uh, yeah. You guys never found me a match.

speaker: Bob
text: Right. Well... actually, that's why I'm calling. We found her, sir. We found your soul mate.

speaker: Ted
text: I don't understand. What happened to Ellen Pierce? Doesn't she run this place?

speaker: Bob
text: Well, my firm bought out the company. You know, we're a high-end meats and textiles conglomerate, but the geniuses at corporate decided they wanted to diversify, so... here I am.

speaker: Ted
text: So I'm in good hands. You found me a match?

speaker: Bob
text: There she is. Your soul mate. That'll be 500 bucks.

speaker: Ted
text: No way. The last time I did this, the girl turned out to be engaged.

speaker: Bob
text: She's not engaged. She's your soul mate. Just read the file.

Ted from 2030: So I read the file. And by God, this woman was perfect. She liked dogs, she spent her summers in North Carolina, she played bass guitar, she did the Times crossword, she played tennis, she liked old movies, her favorite food was lasagna, her favorite book was Love in the Time of Cholera, her favorite singer was Otis Redding and she wanted two kids-- a boy and a girl.

speaker: Ted
text: All right, fine. Set it up.

speaker: Marshall
text: You wanted to see me, so I guess that means we're talking again?

speaker: Barney
text: Will you taste this latte for me? I think they gave me decaf.

speaker: Marshall
text: Tastes normal to me.

speaker: Barney
text: That's what I thought, too. Then I got this e-mail from Butterfield.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh, God!

speaker: Barney
text: It got me as well.

speaker: Marshall
text: Well, then why did you have me drink it?!

speaker: Barney
text: Because now... you're in.

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay. Don't think I'm overlooking the obvious fact that I should just be mad at you. But Executive Mischief Consultant Marshall Eriksen reporting for duty. Let's make that b*st*rd pay. You think that we should brush our teeth first?

speaker: Barney
text: Yeah, it's probably a good idea.
Ted from 2030: So that night I had a blind date with my perfect match. I was so excited, I got there early. But before it even started...

speaker: Ted
text: Lily?

speaker: Lily
text: Hey, Ted, are you busy?

speaker: Ted
text: Um... yes.

speaker: Lily
text: Oh, right. Soul mate. Forgot. Listen, could you take a cab out to Duchess County and change a flat on Marshall's Fiero?

speaker: Ted
text: What? What? No. Can't you just call Marshall?

speaker: Lily
text: Marshall can't know about this. Look, Ted, it's dark, I don't know how to change a tire, and I've stumbled into the beginning of a very scary campfire story. Can you please hurry?

speaker: Ted
text: I can't, I'm waiting...

speaker: Lily
text: Oh, my God, is that a drifter with a hook for a hand? No, drifter, no!

speaker: Ted
text: Come on, Lily.

speaker: Lily
text: But you see my point.

speaker: Ted
text: All right, stay there. I'm on my way.
Ted from 2030: And so, one $90 cab ride later, I was in the middle of nowhere.

speaker: Lily
text: Oh, thank God. I'm so sorry about this. Did you get ahold of your date?

speaker: Ted
text: Yes.

speaker: Lily
text: And was she okay about pushing it back?

speaker: Ted
text: Yes. Because she's perfect. So what am I doing here?

speaker: Lily
text: You can never tell Marshall.

speaker: Ted
text: I won't.

speaker: Lily
text: Ever. Swear. Swear on the lives of your unborn boy and girl.

speaker: Ted
text: I swear on Luke and Leia.

speaker: Lily
text: About a month ago, I started getting insomnia. Marrying Marshall had been all I wanted for a long time. But, now that it was really happening, it seemed kind of huge and scary.

speaker: Ted
text: Did you talk to Marshall about it?

speaker: Lily
text: He wouldn't have understood. He's not exactly nervous about tying the knot. So I spent my nights reading, painting, setting the high score on Super Bomber Man...

speaker: Ted
text: That was you? Awesome!

speaker: Lily
text: I know! I just got in the zone and... Not the point of the story. And then I started thinking about Victoria and how she followed her dream to Germany, and I found that art fellowship.

speaker: Ted
text: Let me guess. It's somewhere far away.

speaker: Lily
text: San Francisco. But it's not like I'm going to do it. The dates conflict with the wedding. But I love painting, and I've always wondered if I'm any good. This was a way to find out. And the interview is tonight. In New Haven.

speaker: Ted
text: You don't want to get married.

speaker: Lily
text: Of course I want to get married. I... It's not like I was ever going to do it. I just... I just really wanted to see if I could get this.

speaker: Ted
text: Lily, we live in the center of art and culture in America. I'm sure you could find a program here that's just as selective. But you chose one in a city 3,000 miles away, and you didn't tell Marshall. I think it's pretty clear what that means.

speaker: Lily
text: Okay, I was... I was having second thoughts. But I'm not any more. I... I mean, this flat tire was a sign. I'm not supposed to do this. I'm supposed to go home and-and be with Marshall. You must think I'm so stupid.

speaker: Ted
text: I don't think you're stupid.

speaker: Lily
text: I love Marshall.

speaker: Ted
text: I know you do. Come here. It's okay. Look... Marriage is big. You're allowed to freak out.

speaker: Lily
text: But why am I the only one? How come Marshall isn't doing anything crazy?

speaker: Marshall
text: So all we need is one large shipping box and 100 white mice.

speaker: Ted
text: All done.

speaker: Lily
text: Ted, let's go to New Haven.

speaker: Ted
text: Lily, don't do this to yourself.

text: I'll say this: There is no quit in that guy. You should fire him.

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay, that, that right there. That attitude is exactly why I won't be in your video. Because GNB doesn't care. They hand out pink slips like they're hors d'oevres. Just last week, I was talking to Arthur...

speaker: Arthur
text: Oh, whoa, you're wearing a green tie now. I'm wearing a green tie.

speaker: Marshall
text: GNB treats people like they're disposable, and I will not be a part of that. Marshall Eriksen does not fire people, period.

speaker: Randy
text: Uh, just want you to know, we are making good progress on this new project. (phone rings) Oh, you gentlemen keep talking, I will answer that. Marshall Eriksen's office. [...] Yeah, I can get that for you. [...] Just a second. Uh... bank. The "B" stands for bank. Okay, Mother, I'll see you tonight. Oh, yikes. I'd better get Mr. Messy a napkin. (loud clattering)

speaker: Marshall
text: Period.

speaker: Lily
text: Just tell me who you slept with!

speaker: Robin
text: Lily, I don't want to get into it, okay?

speaker: Lily
text: Aha, it's someone we know. If it was some ding dong we didn't know, you'd just give me his name.

speaker: Robin
text: Fine. It's Bill Pepper.

speaker: Lily
text: Bill Pepper? Mm-hmm. Kind of a coincidence there happens to be a bill and a pepper shaker here on the table. Any chance you and Bill had a three-way with Fork Napkin? It's someone we know!

speaker: Ted
text: So, I'm assuming you all read the chapters on the Greek Revival architecture. Any questions?

speaker: Zoey
text: Yes. How do you sleep at night?

speaker: Ted
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Zoey
text: It was recently made clear to me that I don't know the first thing about architecture, so here I am.

speaker: Ted
text: Very well, then, let's get started. (clears throat) Some examples of Greek Revival architecture...

speaker: Zoey
text: Ooh! Ooh! Is The Arcadian Greek Revival?

speaker: Ted
text: No.

speaker: Student
text: What's The Arcadian?

speaker: Zoey
text: Oh, it's just this beautiful, old building that Professor Mosby wants to tear down.

speaker: Student
text: What?! No, Professor Mosby loves old buildings. He wouldn't do that. Right, Ted?

speaker: Ted
text: Getting back to Greek Revival...

speaker: Ted
text: I lost them.

speaker: Lily
text: Look, you're new at teaching. In my kindergarten class, I have had plenty of troublesome students. Like Johnny Marley...

speaker: Lily
text: Johnny? Johnny!

speaker: Lily
text: He and that little stuffed horsey raised all kinds of hell. But I have a simple method for shutting down troublemakers. You know that '98 Taurus that's always parked outside? The one with the really annoying alarm?

speaker: Ted
text: We're familiar with it.

speaker: Lily
text: Well, when a kid like Johnny acts up in my class...

speaker: Lily
text: Shuts them right up.

speaker: Ted
text: Lily, my students are adults, and I treat them that way. I'll just give them more candy and make them a mix CD. Problem solved.

speaker: Lily
text: Oh, baby, what's wrong?

speaker: Marshall
text: Something bad happened.

speaker: Marshall
text: Randy, hey, have you seen the...

speaker: Randy
text: Before you get to that, regarding the earlier project I was working on... Voilà!

speaker: Marshall
text: That's the Hermanson contract?

speaker: Randy
text: The Hermanson contract? Oh, man, this is the Filbert contract. Damn it! No... (He shredds the file once again) Anyway, what's your thing?

speaker: Marshall
text: I need the Filbert contract!

speaker: Randy
text: Well, I'll do what I can. But in my experience, twice shredded is fairly permanent.

speaker: Marshall
text: Sorry, Randy, but... this just isn't working out.

speaker: Barney
text: Marshall popped his cherry! Oh! Come on, Marshall, you have to admit, the guy was a disaster. I mean, it reflected badly on the company. He was an embarrassment. A huge embarrassment.

speaker: Lily
text: You slept with Randy!

speaker: Robin
text: What?!

speaker: Lily
text: Why, it's elementary, my dear Scherbatson.

speaker: Lily
text: Your co-host is getting super-popular because of her stupid commercial, "Boats! Boats! Boats!" So, when you arrived at the GNB party after we left, you were feeling vulnerable and drunk. Then, from across the not-so-crowded conference room, your eyes met. And as we all remember... Randy has a unique condition.

speaker: Robin
text: Yeah, your nose is bleeding like a faucet.

speaker: Randy
text: Oh, God, this happens every time I get an erection. I am so sorry.

speaker: Robin
text: That's...exactly what happened.

speaker: Barney
text: See, Marshall, if getting fired is an execution, at least the guy had a last meal. I promise you, tomorrow you'll feel a lot better.

speaker: Marshall
text: Randy, hey, what's going on?

speaker: Randy
text: I just wanted to say no hard feelings.

speaker: Marshall
text: Thank you. So where you headed now?

speaker: Randy
text: Downtown. (Randy jumps into the shredder, Marshall wakes up)

speaker: Marshall
text: No!!

speaker: Lily
text: It's okay, baby.
Ted from 2030: It wasn't okay. So the next morning...

speaker: Marshall
text: Arthur, I'm here because I made a mistake. I fired Randy yesterday.

speaker: Arthur
text: That was a mistake. You should have fired him a year ago.

speaker: Marshall
text: No, sir, that is what's wrong with this company. How can we say "GNB Cares," and then turn around and treat someone like that? I mean, sure, he made a few mistakes but everybody makes mistakes. Like, like Tugboat here. Aw. I bet you he's made some mistakes. And you didn't fire Tugboat, did you?

speaker: Arthur
text: No, I got him fixed, and he calmed down.

speaker: Marshall
text: Exactly-- kind of. Randy doesn't need to be fired. He needs to be fixed.

speaker: Arthur
text: Marshall, we do some pretty bad things around here, but I...

speaker: Marshall
text: No, sir, I'm saying instead of getting rid of someone when they screw up, we should... we should help them. We should nurture them.

speaker: Arthur
text: I changed the ice pack on his crotch every hour for three days. Wow, Eriksen, if you want to un-fire Randy, I support you, because to come in here and say what you just said, well, you've got a couple things that Tugboat doesn't.

speaker: Ted
text: Guys, Prof Rock is a really good mix, okay?

speaker: Student
text: A piece of New York history is being torn down, and all you could say was "Boo freakin' hoo"?

speaker: Ted
text: Boo... freakin'...

speaker: Zoey
text: I may have mentioned our conversation over a session of hacky sack.

speaker: Ted
text: The one day I miss the sack circle, you guys sub her in?

speaker: Zoey
text: Why'd you miss? Too busy tearing down the Statue of Liberty?

speaker: Ted
text: No. I was returning a hot dog costume that you all enjoyed.
Ted from 2030: They were all turning against me, so I figured, what the hell.

speaker: Lily
text: And did it work?

speaker: Ted
text: Like gangbusters. We're buddies again. After class, we hacked a little sack to the thumpin' strains of my Prof Rock CD. And no, none of them had heard the Pixies B-side. Actually, none of them had heard of the Pixies. Or a B-side.

speaker: Randy
text: Hey, guys.

speaker: Barney
text: Uh-oh. I know that smile. Lily, there's no easy way to say this. Marshall's dead. Randy m*rder*d him.

speaker: Lily
text: No. I know why Randy is smiling. You're smiling because of Robin.

speaker: Randy
text: Robin? Like how I think about her when I'm in the shower?

speaker: Ted
text: I'm trying to eat here, buddy.

speaker: Lily
text: No. Because you slept with her on Halloween.

speaker: Randy
text: What? No. I went home, had a shower an-and went to bed.

speaker: Lily
text: You didn't sleep with her?

speaker: Randy
text: No. Even in the shower, the farthest we ever get is hugging.

speaker: Lily
text: So why are you smiling?

speaker: Randy
text: I'll tell you why.

speaker: Marshall
text: This just isn't working out.

Randy, thinking: I'm fired. Great. This is the candle kiosk at the mall all over again. Wait a minute. I can get a severance check. If I don't shred it, I can use that money to start my own brewery. Imagine a beer with my name on it. Randy Wharmpiss, this is the best day of your life.

speaker: Randy
text: Thanks to that severance check, this time next year, you'll all be enjoying a frothy mug of Wharmpiss.

speaker: Marshall
text: Randy, great news! You're not fired!
Randy, wailing: No...!

speaker: Ted
text: Good morning, everybody... Where's my class?

speaker: Zoey
text: Hello, Professor. Ha-boom.

speaker: Marshall
text: I got you your job back, Randy. I thought that you'd be happy.

speaker: Randy
text: But I don't belong here. I'm born to be a brewer! A... a hopsmeister!

speaker: Marshall
text: Well, then quit. No one's stopping you.

speaker: Randy
text: I-I can't. I need my severance check.

speaker: Marshall
text: Well, I'm sorry Randy, but that's called fraud.

speaker: Randy
text: It's not fraud. I'm just asking you to get me a lot of money to not work here and not tell anyone about it.

speaker: Marshall
text: Even if I wanted to fire you, after my talk with Arthur...

speaker: Randy
text: Oh, come on, Arthur can't remember that.

Arthur, entering the room: Marshall, what a memorable talk we had yesterday. Randy, on behalf of everyone at GNB, both in and out of prison, we're sorry. And I want to assure you you will never be fired again. You're going to work here until you die, huh? Green tie? (clears throat) Nice choice.

speaker: Randy
text: Thanks. It brings out my eyes.

speaker: Arthur
text: Yeah. I'll bring out your eyes.

speaker: Marshall
text: Listen, Randy, I'm sorry, but I broke my own moral code once and I felt evil. I will not let GNB change me. I will never fire anyone again ever.

speaker: Randy
text: Oh, we'll see about that.

speaker: Barney
text: Anyhoo, while I got you-- big smile. "We care about making dreams come true," in three, two...

speaker: Randy
text: No!

speaker: Marshall
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Randy
text: Oh, are you unhappy with my performance? Well, I guess I'm fired, then. I'd better turn in my I.D.

speaker: Marshall
text: No, it's actually, um, nice having some of this clutter off my desk. So thank you, Randy.

speaker: Randy
text: And there's more.

speaker: Marshall
text: I don't know what I'm going to use this for, but it's great stuff.

speaker: Randy
text: Now am I fired?

speaker: Marshall
text: I've been meaning to clean out that file cabinet for ages.

speaker: Barney
text: I'm not even here. Randy, the coffee.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh! Okay. Okay. Thank you, Randy. I've been meaning to cut back on my caffeine.

speaker: Barney
text: Here, try this, but really go for it. Remember, this guy ruined your life.

speaker: Marshall
text: That's just the pick-me-up I needed.

text: Speaking of pickups, can we try the first one again?

speaker: Lily
text: Hello.

speaker: Ted
text: It didn't work. They hate me. How do I get them to like me again?

speaker: Lily
text: You don't. Ted, you're their teacher. The only people that like their teachers...

speaker: Ted
text: I like my teachers.
Lily:...are dorks. Except for you, Miles. Ted, you just have to learn to embrace their hatred. Because behind that hatred lies fear. And you can use use that fear, like I did with Johnny Marley.

speaker: Ted
text: Was there more to that story?

speaker: Lily
text: A little bit.

speaker: Ted
text: Lily, you're a psychopath.

speaker: Lily
text: A little bit. Oh, a panda!
Ted from 2030: I thought about Lily's advice. And I figured fear was worth a try.

speaker: Zoey
text: Well, Professor Mosby, is there anything you want to say to us?

speaker: Ted
text: Anyone not in class tomorrow gets an "F."

speaker: Lily
text: You said that?

speaker: Ted
text: Well, technically, they'd get an incomplete, but I thought "F" had a nice, scary ring to it. Right?

speaker: Lily
text: Yeah.

speaker: Robin
text: Hey, guys.

speaker: Lily
text: Robin, who'd you sleep with?

speaker: Robin
text: I told you-- Randy. He was a machine.

speaker: Lily
text: Where's the poop, Robin?

speaker: Robin
text: Fine. I didn't sleep with anyone. The thing is, ever since Becky did that commercial, everyone at work loves her. So, the day after Halloween, I was in a commercial.

speaker: Ted
text: What... Why didn't you tell us?

speaker: Announcer
text: Bladder trouble; it's embarrassing, it's uncomfortable, and it can affect anyone.

speaker: Robin
text: I'm going to the bathroom right now.

speaker: Announcer
text: Neat and discreet adult diapers for anyone.

speaker: Ted
text: Wow! I can't wait to see it.

speaker: Robin
text: Well, hopefully you never will. They said that they might not even use it.
Ted from 2030: It ran for seven years.

speaker: Randy
text: Okay, you win. Maybe trashing your office was a mistake. It's just, uh, as long as I can remember, making beer has been my dream. Wharmpiss? I know it sounds dumb to someone who's already achieved his dream, big-time lawyer at a huge corporation.

speaker: Marshall
text: You think working here is my dream?

speaker: Randy
text: Of course. Anyways, I'll clean this stuff up. Have someone get that dead squirrel out of your desk.

speaker: Marshall
text: Randy. This is delicious. You're fired.

Ted from 2030: Kids, the next morning, my class had the highest attendance it had ever had. And not long after that, Randy used his severance money to start a little brewery. Now you can have a Wharmpiss at every bar in America. And all because...

speaker: Marshall
text: I care about making dreams come true. You got what you need?

speaker: Barney
text: Yep. That's a wrap.
Ted from 2030: Kids, one morning in 2010, I opened the newspaper only to discover an op-ed written by Zoey Pierson. You remember Zoey.

speaker: Zoey
text: Key Ted Mosby's car.

Ted from 2030: In those four column inches, she railed against me and my company, GNB, for wanting to tear down a beautiful old building: The Arcadian. And as if that wasn't bad enough, the piece ran on a Saturday, which as you both know, is Dad's crossword day.

speaker: Ted
text: She ruined crossword day! I can't believe this. She singles me out by name. Calls me a "fat cat." Me and my "fat-cat friends." We're not fat cats.

speaker: Barney
text: Exactly. I say, Marshall, my good man, how's my bow tie?

speaker: Marshall
text: Impeccable, old bean. To industry!

speaker: Barney
text: Ah, bully!

Ted from 2030: Okay, that night we weren't entirely un-fat-catty. You see, every year the Natural History Museum holds its Autumn Spectacular. It's attended by some of the most powerful and important people in New York, and, thanks to Goliath National Bank... us.

speaker: Marshall
text: Look at us, huh? In tuxedos? Can you imagine if our college selves saw us like this?

speaker: Ted
text: They'd pelt us with their Phish bootlegs.

speaker: Marshall
text: Yeah, we were pretty anti-establishment back then. Oh, God, remember Russell?

speaker: Marshall
text: Nice monkey suit, Russell.

speaker: Russel
text: Come on, guys.

speaker: Marshall
text: Oh, I'm sorry, I can't hear you with that corporate noose around your neck. And don't even try showing up to the drum circle this weekend.

speaker: Ted
text: Oh, hey. You guys seen Russell? I'm supposed to drive him to his mom's funeral.

speaker: Robin
text: I wish I knew you guys back then. You know why? Because you can't kick a story in the nuts.

speaker: Lily
text: Hey, we're still those people. One of these days, Marshall's going to quit his job and go to work for the NRDC, and save the world, right, baby?

speaker: Marshall
text: Absotively. But let's just remember, I mean, nobody's the same as they were in college. You know, it's like, I wear a suit to work every day.

speaker: Lily
text: Well, yeah, but you wear it ironically, like Ted's fanny pack.

speaker: Ted
text: Next time we go to Great Adventure, you're carrying your own sunblock.

speaker: Lily
text: Ooh! I love this exhibit. One time when I was a kid, this room was closed for cleaning, so I snuck under the rope.

speaker: Everyone
text: Ooh.

speaker: Barney
text: Wow, that's pretty cool. When I was a kid, I knocked down the blue whale.

speaker: Marshall
text: Okay, the giant blue whale hanging from the ceiling?

speaker: Barney
text: I was six. My uncle Jerry brought me here for the day. He said, "Don't touch anything". To a kid. That's like someone telling us "Don't look at that girl's perky and impossibly symmetrical knockers."

speaker: Everyone
text: Ooh.

speaker: Robin
text: Not bad.

speaker: Barney
text: So, naturally, I snapped the rib off a triceratops, blahbity-blahbity-blue, I knocked down the whale. I'm surprised security didn't stop me on the way in.

speaker: Robin
text: Well, I'm sure they don't remember. I mean, it's been like 30 years since that completely made-up story didn't happen.

speaker: Barney
text: It happened. And these people don't forget. This is not the Natural Stuff That Happened No More Than Five Minutes Ago Museum. Huh?

speaker: Arthur
text: Marshall, Barney, there you are. I want you to meet an old friend of mine from Exeter, George Van Smoot.

speaker: George
text: But you can, and should, call me The Captain.

speaker: Marshall
text: The Captain?

speaker: Barney
text: The Captain?

speaker: Arthur
text: Back in school we met during a production of Guys and Dolls. The Captain was Nathan Detroit to my assistant stage manager. Marshall and Barney here, are the future of Goliath National Bank.

speaker: George
text: Well, ahoy.

speaker: Barney
text: Ahoy.

speaker: Marshall
text: Ahoy, The Captain.

speaker: Arthur
text: The Captain pretty much paid for this entire shindig.

speaker: George
text: Please, enjoy yourselves, have fun, but don't touch anything.

speaker: Marshall
text: Thank you, The Captain.

speaker: Barney
text: Challenge accepted.

speaker: Lily
text: Wow. "The future of Goliath National Bank"?

speaker: Marshall
text: I know, it's so, uh... You know, I totally forgot to tell you, but, um, the other day, Arthur offered me a five-year contract.

speaker: Lily
text: Oh, well, don't turn him down here in public. I broke up with Scooter at the prom. Right before the picture, too.

speaker: Lily
text: So whatever you do, don't tell him here tonight, 'cause...

speaker: Marshall
text: I think I'm going to say yes.

speaker: Barney
text: Ah, that's the stuff.

speaker: Robin
text: I didn't realize you were small potatoes. And to be clear, I am referring to your testicles.

speaker: Barney
text: Impressive. Try this on for size.

speaker: Robin
text: You want to dance? Let's dance.

speaker: Barney
text: I live for the dance.

speaker: Robin
text: Get... your other hand... off my ass.

speaker: Barney
text: Sorry, sorry.

speaker: Lily
text: What do you mean, you're going to say yes?

speaker: Marshall
text: I-I want to keep working at GNB.

speaker: Lily
text: But I thought that you...

speaker: Ted
text: Guys, guys, guys? Architecture fun fact: If you stand right here, and you whisper, a person all the way across the other end of the room hears it like you're standing right next to them. It's one of the most sophisticated pieces of acoustical design in the world. Watch. (whispers): Diarrhea. Right? Right?

speaker: Lily
text: But a five-year contract. I thought you hated GNB.

speaker: Marshall
text: Look, I don't hate all of it. Tonight's fun. Take a look around. I mean, this is pretty high-class.
Ted, whispering: Poo-poo. Poo-poo platter.

speaker: Ted
text: Zoey? Well, well, well.

speaker: Zoey
text: You have got to be kidding me.

speaker: Ted
text: So, what are we protesting tonight? Rising cost of jet fuel? The government's oppressive top hat and monocle tax?

speaker: Zoey
text: And what are you doing here? Oh, right. Beautiful old building... you're here to knock it down. Can I finish my drink first?

speaker: George
text: Darling, there you are.

speaker: Zoey
text: Ted, this is my husband.

speaker: Ted
text: Yeah, old stuff's great.

speaker: Robin
text: Mmm. Ah, this Scotch is good. How's your drink?

speaker: Barney
text: This is ridiculous. We are two grown adults standing among the greatest collection of natural artifacts in the Western hemisphere, and look at what we're doing.

speaker: Robin
text: You're right.

speaker: Barney
text: Want to go touch a bunch of stuff?

speaker: Robin
text: Yeah, I do.

speaker: Ted
text: So, Captain. How'd you get that name, anyway?

speaker: George
text: Gave it to myself. A real man chooses his own name.

speaker: Ted
text: Well, pleased to meet you, Captain. I'm Galactic President Superstar McAwesomeville.

speaker: Zoey
text: This is Ted.

speaker: George
text: Capital. Honey, I may cut out early. I have to go check up on the boat.

speaker: Ted
text: The boat? There's a boat? You must tell me about this boat, Captain.

speaker: George
text: Well, she's an 85-foot sloop.

speaker: Ted
text: She!

speaker: George
text: Do you like boats? Does the sea call to you like it calls to me?

speaker: Ted
text: Yes. The sea is all like, "Ted, come hang out."

speaker: George
text: I like Galactic President Superstar McAwesomeville. You're coming on the boat sometime. Stepping off.

speaker: Ted
text: Man, I wish me and my dad were as close as you guys are.

speaker: Zoey
text: Oh. You want to make this personal? Okay. Destroy Ted Mosby. Now it's personal.

speaker: Ted
text: No, if I wanted to make it personal, I'd call you a bored little trophy wife who likes to play activist when the shops on 5th Avenue are closed.

speaker: Zoey
text: You're going down.

speaker: Ted
text: Down where? To the yacht club? Oh! I would love to. W-w-wait. I'm half Jewish, will that be a problem?

speaker: Lily
text: So what about becoming an environmental lawyer? What about saving the world?
Ted, whispering: Wieners.

speaker: Marshall
text: That was a great dream. But we have a mortgage, and we're trying to have kids. We're grown-ups now, Lily.

speaker: Ted
text: Wieners and gonads.

speaker: Lily
text: What would College You say if he heard what you were saying right now?

speaker: Marshall
text: Honestly? Probably something pretentious, and pseudo-intellectual, like...

speaker: Ted
text: Boogers.

speaker: Marshall
text: We all change, Lily. You know, you don't spell "women" with a "Y" anymore. And I'm okay with that. And you need to be okay with the fact that I may never become an environmental lawyer.

speaker: Lily
text: So how long have you felt this way?

speaker: Marshall
text: Honestly? Since my first day at GNB.

speaker: Ted
text: Hershey squirts.

speaker: Robin
text: Hey. How do you like my date's tux? Ooh! Uh, a-thank you! Oh, none for him. He's stuffed.

speaker: Ted
text: Oh! Zoey! There you are. Oh, my God. You have a monocle. Is this real? Is this really happening?

speaker: Zoey
text: Can you excuse us for a moment? Let's go for a walk.

speaker: Ted
text: Good luck killing James Bond. (Zoey takes Ted away) Are we allowed in here?

speaker: Zoey
text: What do you want from me?

speaker: Ted
text: I want my crossword day back. Okay? Go live your perfect little life, and leave me the hell alone.

speaker: Zoey
text: My life isn't perfect.

speaker: Ted
text: Oh, please, what's your biggest problem? Having to sail back to the marina because the Captain's all out of white Zin? Oh. Great. Now you're crying. Like that's going to get my sympathy.
Ted from 2030: It did.

speaker: Lily
text: You've known about this for two and a half years? So every time you've talked about wanting to be an environmental lawyer since then, that was a lie.

speaker: Marshall
text: Technically, I never lied. You asked me questions, and I responded with made-up words.

speaker: Lily
text: What?

speaker: Lily
text: So, you'll probably quit GNB in a couple years, right?

speaker: Marshall
text: Affirmatootly.

speaker: Lily
text: And become an environmental lawyer?

speaker: Marshall
text: Yepskerdoodles.
